keyTakeAways: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant (ZNPP) has been without off-site power for four weeks, the longest blackout since the war began.
Work is underway to restore power after the establishment of rare UN-backed ceasefire zones, allowing repair crews to operate safely.
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) emphasized that off-site power restoration is critical for nuclear safety and security.
Both Ukrainian and Russian sides accuse each other of causing the blackout: Ukraine claims Russia intentionally cut power; Russia blames Ukrainian shelling.
The plant has lost connection to the grid 10 times since the war began, highlighting the ongoing threat to nuclear safety from military aggression.
Russia continues to conduct strikes on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure, including a recent attack on the Slavutych substation that caused a three-hour blackout at the former Chernobyl plant.
Ukrainian officials assert that Russian military aggression, occupation of the plant, and shelling of energy infrastructure are the root causes of the crisis.
Russian-controlled plant staff stated that military support from the Russian defense ministry was essential to allow repairs in an area under active shelling.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Work is underway to restore power to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant (ZNPP) in Ukraine after four weeks without off-site power, the longest blackout since the war began. The restoration efforts are being enabled by rare UN-backed ceasefire zones, allowing repairs to resume. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) stresses that off-site power is essential for nuclear safety, and both Ukraine and Russia have accused each other of causing the outage—Ukraine claims Russian sabotage, Russia blames Ukrainian shelling. The plant has lost connection to the grid ten times since the war started, and ongoing attacks on Ukraine's energy infrastructure, including a recent strike on Slavutych, have heightened regional risks. Ukrainian officials maintain that Russian military aggression and occupation are the primary threats to nuclear safety, while Russian forces claim their military presence is necessary to protect workers from shelling.
title: Work underway to restore power at Ukrainian nuclear plant as UN announces rare local ‘ceasefire zones’
